explanation: The report is not correct. Rule 21.17 concerns use of string.h functions that can read past object bounds. The code in check_nonce_nc uses memcmp(nn->nonce, nonce, noncelen) and accesses nn->nonce[noncelen]. These are guarded at runtime: check_nonce_nc returns early if noncelen > MAX_DIGEST_NONCE_LENGTH, and nn->nonce is declared as char nonce[MAX_DIGEST_NONCE_LENGTH + 1], so indexing nn->nonce[noncelen] (0..MAX_DIGEST_NONCE_LENGTH) and comparing up to noncelen bytes are within the allocated object. The nonce argument passed to check_nonce_nc comes from earlier code that ensures unquoted.len == NONCE_STD_LEN(digest_size) before calling check_nonce_nc, so memcmp is given a valid buffer length (memcmp does not require NUL-termination). The mhd_assert no-op does not matter here because actual runtime checks (the MAX_DIGEST_NONCE_LENGTH test and the prior unquoted.len check) prevent out-of-bounds accesses. Agent A’s scenario about strlen(username) refers to a different function (digest_auth_check_all_inner) and not to check_nonce_nc; it is therefore not a valid demonstration that check_nonce_nc violates MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17.
